subject: Re: [junit] Re: Test Names and rerunning Test instances for Parameterized Tests
msgSnippet: ... Actually, this is a much larger request, in terms of its demands on Eclipse and the user.  The size and low vote count put it lower down on my priority
messageBody:
Eugene Kuleshov wrote:

> Here is the request I've filled in about 2 years ago which is
> describing this issue from a different angle.
>
> Allow to choose required JUnit test cases
> https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=40598

Actually, this is a much larger request, in terms of its demands on
Eclipse and the user. The size and low vote count put it lower down on
my priority list than (especially) full native JUnit 4 support.

> I've also filled number of others requests against Eclipse JUnit
> integration. Please take a look. If others from this list are also
> using Eclipse and like to see some of them implemented it would make
> sense to vote for them:

It certainly would. Votes and discussion on Eclipse bugs are taken
seriously by the Eclipse developers.

> >> It seems violating the concept of annotations. You should not
> >>annotate the behaviour, but rather define enough metadata that can be
> >>used by the tool to decide how to behave.
> >
> > Tricky, maybe, but violating is a strong word. :) Can you give an
> > example of how using annotations to identify the Runner that should be
> > used by a particular class might be a problem? Thanks,
>
> Let me ask you another question first. Why would you need to have a
> different runner for some specific test?

You may of course ask another question first, but I hope that I can
still get an answer to my question. :) One thing that I may have
managed to make unclear is that the meaning of Runner has changed in
JUnit 4. Now there is a JUnitCore class responsible for running an
entire set of test classes. Each test class has a separate Runner
instance invoked, which knows how to run the tests in that class. There
are four runners that are currently shipping with JUnit 4:

* TestClassRunner, for default JUnit 4 test classes
* OldTestClassRunner, for implementers of the JUnit 3
junit.framework.Test interface
* AllTests, for classes that do not implement Test, but declare a
suite() method
* Parameterized, for the proposed new JUnit 4 parameterized test API

> This doesn't sound right to me to begin with and may also make more
> difficult to integrate with different tools (including coverage
> metrisc, etc).

There might be problems. I've tried it out and liked it, and I can't
necessarily see how coverage metrics would be affected by the new Runner
idea. But I'd definitely be interested in your experiences with it.
Have you tried it?

David Saff
